content.text: Note that, unlike javascript, the expressions you put inside a string must themselves be of type
, otherwise you'll get a type error.
Â form, and can take one or more arguments.
At the top level, you can define a function with
, to make it be globally available.
Functions can be "partially applied", by providing only some of the expected arguments. The result will be another function, that's expecting the remaining arguments.
You redefine a variable in the same let, using the previous value.
Â is the way to define new custom types, similar to
A type consists of a name, optionally some type variables, and a list of constructors, which themselves may have arguments, or may not.

A very common type is the "optional" (called "Maybe" in haskell). It has a type variable and two constructors, and is used in places where in JavaScript or other places you might have a "nullable" value.
"Quoting" allows us to get at the AST (or CST) at "runtime", so that we can test out our own parser and compiler :)
Â is for the CST (Concrete Syntax Tree), which is what the parser consumes to produce expressions, types, patterns, and toplevels.
Feel free to define things "out of order"; they will be evaluated in the correct dependency order.
Here's an overview of all of the syntax of version 1 of our language, which will be sufficient to fully self-host the parser, code generator, and type checker.
The next few documents will go into detail about the language design, so you don't need to internalize everything immediately, but you can use this as a reference as you go forward.
Type aliases are helpful when you have a complex type that you'll be referring to a lot. They will get substituted in to the bodies of
, and have no impact on the type inference algorithm, and no runtime representation.
Tuples are a special-cased syntax for a normal userland data type. Any time you see
, it will be translated into "nested pairs", so in this case

. This applies to expressions, patterns, and types. They are handy for when you want to group some things together, but you don't want to define a whole new data type for it (such as "returning multiple values from a function").
Making purity & immutability a little less cumbersome

Because our language is fully immutable, some things can require a lot of plumbing that can really get in the way of readability. For example, in our type inference algorithm we'll need to keep track of an incrementing integer so we can produce unique ids for type variables. Without a specialized syntax, this would require passing the

variable into -- and out of -- almost every function, which would get really annoying. Fortunately, our friends in haskell-land have come up with a nice way of abstracting this out, called "do notation". We'll be taking inspiration from this for our
would be something akin to swift's
suffix, allowing us to have nice error handling without resorting to throwing exceptions.

needs to be a "wrapped value" (in this case, a

So this was an example using the do-notation with the
type for handling errors, but in the "Self-Hosted Type Inference" document we'll be using a somewhat more complicated version, which will allow us the to have the illusion of mutable state :).
This tuple type is a type we'll be using throughout the tutorial
